title: High Computer Resource interaction with Twitch, Firefox, and Windows Explorer?
content:
TL;DR Incoming, I am so sorry

im going to be honest here, i got no clue if this is some interaction with the recent Firefox 110.0.1 update/release, or something on twitch's end, but lately, when i try to watch any sort of twitch stream, no matter the person streaming, i see an increase of computer resources firefox uses when watching twitch on it. I only noticed after trying to expand/shrink my window and seeing it take at least 2 seconds minimum to actualize. Also, and i have tested this multiple times, this affects my Windows Explorer process and causes a marked increase in CPU & Power usage (minimum of 20% cpu increase, Power Usage at 'Very High'). I did an entire battery of error checking with windows own default tools, chkdsk, dism, sfc, nothing found. Virus checking found nothing. Then i did a chkdsk /r /f scan and that seemingly mitigated the problem but didnt do away with it, it still happens, i even disabled all my extensions, and made another firefox profile (firefox.exe -p) and tried to see if it was something in my default that i tweaked wrong, nope, the high resource usage still affecting firefox and windows explorer

i don't know if what im experiencing is something to report to the bugzilla website, if the solution is something easier, or not, but.....what the heck is going on, and how can i get this taken care of. Also, id di try to see if microsoft edge would be affected as well, but its not, whatever the issue is, it lies with firefox

title: Firefox memory leak
content:
Hi, I am new to the forums, but I have been using Firefox all my life. A couple of days ago I came across a strange issue which I can replicate a number of times. When I play a YouTube video and move the browser left and right across my desktop screen while the video is playing I can eventually get Firefox to use all my 65gb of ram to the point my entire pc becomes unresponsive. It's a brand new build, I have tested my ram via memtest86, prime95 large ftt which stress test imc and the ram all have passed. Other browsers do not exhibit this behaviour I have tested brave, chrome, opera normal and gx, na edge. They all work fine when I repeat the steps of the Firefox issue. It does seem disabling hardwares acceleration solves the issue. What is the cause here? Anyway I can fix this?

Please see attached a URL to the issue I made a video and uploaded it my Gmail drive: https://drive.google.com/file/d/19QxCcSOqcoVRIXVQQjx_jnniWSTKKCcP/view?usp=sharing

I have posted this on the bugzilla page but no one has got back to me. I was hoping here someone can test this and replicate the issue.

And it moves constantly. Very annoying.

If you try and hide the dock, nope, it reappears.

The "solution" is to turn off Handoff in macOS system settings, but that takes away a lot of functionality I need.

Is there an internal fix within Firefox settings to stop this constant new icon to move all the time?

Thanks!

title: Disable silent updates of Firefox on Ubuntu
content:
I want to stop Firefox from silently updating in the background during browsing sessions. When it finishes updating like this, currently open tabs stop working and I can no longer open new tabs. The only fix is to restart Firefox. This is a problem if I am, for instance, going through a set of web forms as the information I enter will then be deleted and I have to start again.

When I have used Firefox on Windows, the requirement to restart Firefox to install updates has always been indicated by some change to the settings button on the top right of the window. With Ubuntu, the update is downloaded and installed without any action from my part, and given that it is quite disruptive this is unacceptable.

I have tried a number of ways of changing this, none of which work. Under the general settings tab, there are no options for changing the way updates are handled. Settings under about:config appear to do nothing. I have app.update.auto set to false, and app.update.notifyDuringDownload is set to true. I have attempted to circumvent these by setting a policy using the policies.json:

{ 

 "policies": {    "DisableAppUpdate": true,    "AppAutoUpdate": false,    "BackgroundAppUpdate": false  }

}

None of these have made the slightest change to how Firefox handles updates.

I am running Firefox 110.0.1 (64 bit) on Ubuntu 20.04.5 LTS, but I should point out that this has been a problem for the last several years of Firefox versions on the same OS.
creator: ryan.j.thomas1

title: Uncommon download alert vs signed application - will EV change anything?
content:
Hi,

from time to time I'm facing the issue which is reported to me by my clients, that signing the application (for example .exe files) with commercial code signing certificate does not help them to get rid of "Uncommon download" notification when their application is downloaded.

I'm trying (and I hope that someone will help me to answer to this question) to figure out if signing the application with EV code signing certificate should help in this case? Personally often I can't even prove that the problem with specific file exists, because when I download the example file, I'm not notified about uncommon download, but screenshots from my clients are real.

Of course I've read any document I found describing how the Google Safe Browsing mechanism works and I do understand that it is developed to protect the users, but my question about EV certificate is still wondering me.

Microsoft advisor described that EV signing may help for Edge users: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/886010/avoiding-microsoft-edge-isnt-commonly-downloaded-w. What about Firefox?

I'm ready to provide some examples if needed but the question seems global to me.

Best regards, Paula

title: Disable Updates - PERMANENTLY - On Firefox!
content:
How to PERMANENTLY disable updates on all versions of Firefox from the latest backward.

Don't try and re-school us on allowing auto updates. Please allow us the choice. There are many people with many legitimate reasons for wanting and needing to turn this off and have it stay turned off. Those of us using various retro versions of Firefox also need this option. No further explanations needed!

Lets start with putting the choice to Never Update back in the options.

Worse yet, this program re-writes registry keys and options settings when the computer and/or program is restarted, so that the update options are changed back to the default auto install. This is causing problems on internal networks to the point of making the browser unusable.

What about time lost in having to turn this off each time the computer is restarted. For instance, if you are using a laptop in a limited data situation. You have turned this off previously. You shut the machine down for the night. In the morning you need to connect and do work and turn the machine on while you walk away for a minute because it's set to do mail and make connections to work network automatically. When you return, its stuck because auto updates are running. The internal work network connection times out and that system is locked up. So now you have to call IT. Morning lost.

As private users, not being able to turn this off permanently is making us stop using Firefox altogether. We want sovereignty over OUR computers. We paid for them and feel we can throw them out the window if we want! (I've done this many times.) Remember the customer being "right"!

Repeat after me. WE OWN OUR COMPUTERS! We are the final word on them! You need to understand that.

How about just a succinct answer on how to do this. "Anything less is uncivilized."
creator: info8810

title: Firefox ESR 102.80 issues with Sharepoint and OneDrive
content:
When trying to open Sharepoint or OneDrive Sites I receive either an 401 Access denied or a: We are sorry, something went wrong.

The issue is actually described in https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1373433 It seems that it broke again now. There are also other people having this problem: https://www.reddit.com/r/sysadmin/comments/11aot6r/firefox_10280esr_seems_to_have_broken/


If I either clear all cache, active logins and cookies or reload with STRG + F5 it will work temporarily. Setting dom.serviceWorkers.navigationPreload.enabled to False fixes it completely.

title: Email bounce detection issue when creating new account
content:
I’m trying to create a new Firefox Sync for a family member and the email they are using for it is a business email. When trying to sign up Firefox said the email was bounced and to check the address. We know the address is right because we received the email code. My guess is that Firefox mistakes the auto reply email with a bounce back. As I said this is a commercial account so they have an auto reply setup (“Thanks for reaching out, we will get back to you etc”). Now I’m waiting for 15’ before I can try to sign in again because it locked me out. I understand the feature is supposed to be helpful but if you can’t reliably detect real bounce backs it should be disabled. If I can’t use this address to create the account because of this my options are: - Tell this person to create a new email - Ask them to disable the auto reply in their current email - Don’t use Sync at all

None of these options is desirable or practical.
creator: diegus831

title: Videos don't work on Firefox
content:
hello , I have win 11 laptop where Firefox is my default browser , and recently it seems that I can't play any videos on Firefox and I keep getting this error : if playback doesn't begin shortly, try restarting your device Youtube seems to be working on other browsers and I tried every single suggestion out there to fix this but nothing helped ,examples:

1. Retarting device , browser 2. updating device , browser 3.disabling hardware accleration on FF 4.checked for driver updates for my GPU 5.disabled any extensions or add-ons 6.run FF in tshoot mode 7.checked that windows media fetaure is installed 

it only works when I run FF in compatibility mode /windows 8 , which is not ideal for me. can you please help ?

Regards, Haneen
creator: haneenqaderi

title: Can't open Youtube videos sometimes even after cearing cookies, cache, and history
content: Sometimes I'll try to open a YouTube video and will receive nothing but the following error. I've looked up a couple guides on the subject which said to clear cookies, cache, site history, and to select "no proxy" in network settings and nothing has helped. My cookie settings are on "standard".
creator: lane.roswell013
